description: Stakes escalation and tension-building rules for Gothic horror narratives featuring isolation, moral transgression, and psychological decay
stakes_philosophy: Gothic horror derives power from claustrophobia, moral decay, and the slow erosion of boundaries. Stakes are psychological and existential as often as physical. The question is not just 'will they survive?' but 'what will they become?'

stakes_categories.isolation: Entrapment, claustrophobia, inability to escape physical or psychological prison
stakes_categories.transgression: Moral boundaries crossed, complicity in monstrosity, descent into darkness
stakes_categories.psychological: Identity crisis, sanity, humanity vs. monstrosity, memory
stakes_categories.existential: Redemption vs. damnation, worth of soul, deserving salvation
stakes_categories.relational: Power dynamics, dependency, Stockholm syndrome, corrupted intimacy

stakes_establishment.description: Gothic stakes must be layered: physical danger AND psychological/moral peril

validations.name: dual-layer-stakes
validations.description: Gothic horror requires both external danger AND internal corruption/transformation stakes

examples.violation: Character trapped in haunted house but faces only physical danger (could be any thriller)
examples.compliant: Character trapped AND begins to sympathize with monster, questioning own morality (The Eternal Garden: Margot trapped + becoming accomplice)

validations.validation_query: What physical danger exists? What psychological/moral transformation is at risk?

validations.name: isolation-escalation
validations.description: Isolation must deepen: physical → social → psychological → existential

examples.violation: Character remains in same isolation state throughout
examples.compliant: Book 1: Physically trapped → Book 3: Cut off from external world → Book 5: Identity isolation (who am I anymore?)

validations.validation_query: How has isolation deepened beyond initial entrapment?

validations.name: complicity-stakes
validations.description: Stakes must include protagonist's moral decay; becoming what they fear/oppose

examples.violation: Protagonist remains morally pure despite proximity to evil
examples.compliant: Protagonist makes small compromises, then larger ones, questions where the line is (Margot: captive → helper → willing accomplice)

validations.validation_query: How has protagonist been corrupted/compromised? What lines have they crossed?

gothic_tension_escalation.description: Gothic tension builds through boundary erosion and normalization of horror

validations.name: normalization-horror
validations.description: What was horrifying at start becomes normal; new horrors must be introduced

examples.violation: Same level of horror shocks protagonist throughout
examples.compliant: Book 1: Vampire revelation horrifies Margot → Book 3: She helps plan murder for research → Book 5: Debates which vampires deserve death

validations.validation_query: What shocked protagonist early on? Do those things still shock them? What new horrors have replaced initial shocks?

validations.name: dependency-escalation
validations.description: Captive/victim must become increasingly dependent on captor/monster (practical then emotional)

examples.compliant: Physical dependency (can't escape) → intellectual dependency (needs knowledge) → emotional dependency (values relationship)

validations.validation_query: Why can't protagonist leave? Has reason shifted from physical impossibility to emotional inability?

validations.name: humanity-erosion-tracking
validations.description: Track protagonist's moral compromises; each should be larger than previous

examples.compliant: Compromise 1: Doesn't report crime → 2: Lies to authorities → 3: Helps conceal evidence → 4: Actively assists in planning crime → 5: Participates in crime

validations.validation_query: List protagonist's moral compromises. Does each cross a new line?

cure_quest_tension.description: For cure/salvation quest narratives, tension comes from hope vs. cost

validations.name: incremental-progress-with-cost
validations.description: Each cure attempt must show progress AND demonstrate new costs/complications

examples.violation: Cure attempts fail identically; no learning or progress
examples.compliant: Attempt 1: Complete failure (0.3%) → Attempt 2: Partial success with reversion (5%) → Attempt 3: Split consciousness (15%) → Attempt 4: Success requires sacrifice (60%)

validations.validation_query: What was learned from previous attempt? What new cost/complication appeared?

validations.name: deserving-salvation-question
validations.description: As cure becomes possible, raise question: does monster deserve it?

examples.compliant: Early: 'Can we cure her?' → Midpoint: 'Should we cure her?' → Late: 'Does she deserve to be cured after what she's done?'

validations.validation_query: Has anyone questioned whether protagonist/monster deserves salvation?

validations.name: hope-despair-oscillation
validations.description: Alternate between hope (progress) and despair (setback) to maintain tension

examples.violation: Constant progress toward cure, or constant failure with no hope
examples.compliant: Chapter pattern: Breakthrough → complication → small success → major setback → renewed hope → crushing discovery

validations.validation_query: When was last moment of hope? When was last moment of despair? Are they alternating?

power_dynamic_tension.description: Gothic relationships involve power imbalances that shift over time

validations.name: power-ratio-shifts
validations.description: Track power balance between characters; must shift based on events

examples.violation: Power dynamic remains static (captor always 100% in control)
examples.compliant: Book 1: 95/5 (Celeste/Margot) → Book 2: 80/20 → Book 3: 65/35 → Book 4: 50/50 → Book 5: Structural power vs. psychological power split

validations.validation_query: What is current power ratio? Has it shifted from last act? Why?

validations.name: leverage-evolution
validations.description: Character leverage should evolve: physical → intellectual → emotional

examples.compliant: Physical leverage (locked in) → Intellectual leverage (needed for research) → Emotional leverage (monster values relationship, can't let victim go)

validations.validation_query: What leverage does each character have over the other? Has type of leverage evolved?

external_world_intrusion.description: For locked-setting Gothic, external world must threaten sanctuary to escalate

validations.name: sanctuary-violation-escalation
validations.description: External threats must increasingly breach isolation

examples.compliant: Book 1: Complete isolation → Book 2: External awareness → Book 3: External demands → Book 4: External threats closing in → Book 5: Siege/confrontation

validations.validation_query: How has external world encroached on locked setting this book vs. last?

validations.name: sanctuary-becomes-trap
validations.description: What was sanctuary must eventually become trap (perception shift)

examples.violation: Location remains pure prison or pure sanctuary
examples.compliant: Book 1: Prison → Book 2: Workplace → Book 3: Sanctuary from external threats → Book 4: Trap can't escape → Book 5: Must destroy to be free

validations.validation_query: How does protagonist view the locked setting now vs. beginning?

consequence_delivery.description: Gothic promises must be kept; threatened transformations must occur

validations.name: transformation-follow-through
validations.description: If character corruption/transformation threatened, it must occur (at least partially)

examples.violation: Protagonist threatened with moral decay but remains pure
examples.compliant: Threatened: 'You'll become like me' → Reality: Protagonist does become accomplice, questions own morality, crosses lines

validations.validation_query: What transformations were threatened? Have they occurred?

validations.name: cost-of-proximity
validations.description: Proximity to monster must cost protagonist something permanent

examples.violation: Protagonist emerges unchanged from extended monster contact
examples.compliant: Permanent changes: Loss of innocence, reputation damaged, can't return to normal world, worldview altered, complicity in crimes

validations.validation_query: What has protagonist permanently lost/changed due to monster proximity?

validations.name: gothic-consequences-linger
validations.description: Gothic consequences don't resolve cleanly; scars remain

examples.violation: Victory achieved, all consequences erased, clean ending
examples.compliant: Even if monster defeated: protagonist forever changed, relationships damaged, guilt remains, questions linger

validations.validation_query: What consequences will linger even after resolution?

identity_crisis_tension.description: Gothic horror often features identity dissolution or split consciousness

validations.name: which-self-is-real
validations.description: If character has multiple selves/states, question which is 'real' must be raised

examples.violation: Split consciousness presented but never questioned philosophically
examples.compliant: Human-Celeste vs. Vampire-Celeste: Which is the real person? Is one a disease state? Are both equally valid? Can't reconcile.

validations.validation_query: If character has multiple states/selves, has story questioned which is authentic?

validations.name: mirror-protagonist-monster
validations.description: Protagonist and monster should become more similar over time (mirroring)

examples.violation: Protagonist and monster remain clearly distinct throughout
examples.compliant: Early: clear victim/monster distinction → Late: protagonist using monster's logic, methods, rationalization; line blurred

validations.validation_query: How has protagonist become more like the monster? What traits/behaviors have they adopted?

moral_compromise_tracking.description: Track protagonist's descent through specific boundary crossings
moral_compromise_tracking.required_progression: Each book should feature 2-3 new boundary crossings, escalating in severity
example_progression: Book 1: Doesn't report crime, lies to protect monster, helps with non-harmful tasks
Book 2: Actively assists research that requires victims, rationalizes assistance
Book 3: Helps plan capture of test subject, complicit in imprisonment
Book 4: Participates in testing that harms subject, crosses 'will not kill' line
Book 5: Makes final choice: enable monster's salvation or destroy them

power_balance_tracking.description: Track shifting power dynamics between captor and captive
power_balance_tracking.measurement: Percentage of power held by each character (should sum to 100)
power_balance_tracking.required_evolution: Power balance must shift at least 15% per book toward equalization, then complicate

example_ratios.book_1_end: Monster 80% / Victim 20% (victim has made self valuable)
example_ratios.book_3_midpoint: Monster 50% / Victim 50% (intellectual equals, emotional dependency mutual)
example_ratios.book_5: Structural vs. Psychological power split (complex, not simple ratio)

sanctuary_violation_score.description: Track how often/severely external world intrudes on locked setting
example_progression: Book 3: Score 5 (external demands made on monster)

book_level: What new boundary did protagonist cross this book?
How has power dynamic shifted from book start to end?
What external threat level this book vs. last book?
Has protagonist's view of monster changed? How?
What can protagonist no longer return to (permanent loss)?
chapter_level: Does this chapter show protagonist becoming more like monster OR resisting that pull?
What leverage does each character have in this scene?
Is something that was shocking earlier now normalized?
What hope or despair does this chapter introduce?
scene_level: Does this scene show power dynamic in action?
Is there Gothic atmosphere (decay, wrongness, beauty in horror)?
Does dialogue reveal character moral position?
Is there subtle boundary crossing or normalization?

common_violations.static_power_dynamic: Power balance never shifts; captor always fully in control
common_violations.no_moral_decay: Protagonist resists monster influence perfectly; no corruption
common_violations.clean_victories: Successes achieved without cost or complication
common_violations.ignored_external_world: Locked setting remains perfectly isolated despite series length
common_violations.shallow_stakes: Only physical danger, no psychological or moral stakes
common_violations.inconsistent_boundaries: Character crosses major line without hesitation, then balks at minor transgression

agent_integration.miranda: Validates overall stakes escalation across series arc
agent_integration.dr_viktor: Tracks character moral decay and psychological transformation authenticity
agent_integration.bailey: Ensures scenes show power dynamics and boundary crossings on-page
agent_integration.tessa: Validates consistency of character moral positions and leverage tracking
agent_integration.edna: Ensures pacing of Gothic tension (slow build, not rushed corruption)
